chapter.title: Getting ELinks up and running
chapter.para: Installing ELinks should be pretty easy on most systems. Below is described the hole process of getting the sources, configuring the compilation and compiling and installing.

sect1.title: Getting the source
sect1.para:
There are various methods of requiring the source code for ELinks all you have to do is find one that suites your need. Basically there are two flavors:
stable
The hopefully rock solid version of ELinks that is well tested but not fully up to date. This should be considered if you are going to maintain ELinks on systems with lot's of users.
development or unstable
The bleeding edge version of ELinks for the brave ones. This should be considered if you want to be up to date or need some specific feature. Also consider this flavor if you want to contribute to ELinks by testing it. (This of course requires you to mail us. See more about this in ).
Whether you prefer stable or development there are two methods of getting them.

sect2.title: Downloading a tarball
sect2.para: Tarballs are good if you do not install/upgrade ELinks very often but rather when important fixes or releases have been made announced. Tarballs are also the installation form that requires least available tools for building the program. More about this in .

Tarballs of the various flavors are available from the download page at ELinks homepage (see ). Besides the various releases you can download daily generated CVS snapshots of both the stable and development branches.

sect2.title: The CVS way
sect2.para: If you regularly upgrade your ELinks (using the development) flavor you will find getting ELinks the CVS way much more easy. Also this way you might save some bandwidth since you wont have to download the full package every time.

sect2.title: Requirements
sect2.para: To successfully install ELinks all that is required is GNU make and a C compiler. If you want to install directly from CVS it is also required that automake and autoconf is installed on your system.
